item.title: Massive pile of rubbish blocks access to 4 flats, 24th February
item.description:
Over the past few months, a large pile of rubbish including small free stumps has accumulated at the entrance to an alley off of Northumberland Park, that provides access to 4 Bexley Road flats (212a - 218a) and is in regular use by employees of the Northumberland Heath Tesco. Easy access has become increasingly difficult, and the pile of rubbish has led to weekly waste disposal teams assuming it is the fault of residents of the flats and refusing to pick up, leading to regular missed collections of black sacks and food waste caddies kept further down the alley in neat bins. Over the weekend of Feb 21/22, more bags and even electric appliances have appeared in the pile. A large increase in vermin has been noted in the alley, as well as rubbish from the pile constantly being dragged down it and onto the pavement, likely by foxes. Bones and food scraps also appear very consistently in the entrance of the alley, though it is unclear if this is from the same pile or separate occasions of littering as it seems to occur every night. Cleanliness and accessibility are the key concerns as one of the residents of one of the alleyway’s flats uses a walking stick and can find having to traverse the refuse very difficult, especially late at night due to the lack of lighting.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 198-200, Northumberland Park, Northumberland Heath, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Where cycling lane ends (southbound) and is filtered onto Royal College Street, 24th February
item.description:
About 2 weeks ago, I have witnessed a near-miss between a cyclist and HGV lorry which was incredibly scary: the cycling path ends and cyclists need to join Royal College St and it often happens that cars simply keep going and will not slow down to allow cyclists to join safely, even when obvious. There is an inactive (I cannot even remember whether this has ever worked?) road sign, probably intended to make motorist aware, however this is turned to side and not visible. This particular HGV driver was going at high speed and did not slow down, the Uber bike cyclist was almost run over and could have gotten badly injured or killed. Please activate the illuminated road sign and make drivers aware cyclists have right of way here.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Royal College Street, Kentish Town, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Trolly, car windscreen and fencing left on grass verge, 24th February
item.description:
There has been a lot of litter and several items left on this grass verge. Not only is the litter building up but all the items (trolley, car windscreen and fencing rails) have all been left on this verge for months now. It’s horrible and looks horrible. As a result people are littering constantly on this grass verge.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Carlton Place, Longlands, Greater London

item.title: Urgent matter needed bus stop massive pothole needs filling in road knee repair as soon as possible, 24th February
item.description:
Pothole has been there since last year October as of now the pothole has gotten worse as you can see in the picture. The cone has been placed in the centre of this pothole previous patch Work has failed. This is why the bus stop as well. Bus stop E this is also dangerous for cyclists who can go into this pothole also dangerous for the buses as buses can get damaged with your potholes.

Nearest address to the pin placed on the map (from OS Places API): Woolwich Road, Greenwich

item.title: Abandoned caravan for months, 24th February
item.description:
This caravan has been parked up for several months. It doesn't have any licence plate on display and it in a residents parking place. So it is illegally parked and should be ticketed and removed. There is no license plate or any way to identify the owner.

Nearest address to the pin placed on the map (from OS Places API): Southborough Road, Hackney, London
